Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference, the 4th Northeastern Analysis Meeting (NEAM 2019) that will be held from October 4 to October 6, 2019 at Syracuse University. The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of complex analysis, nonlinear analysis, geometric analysis and partial differential equations.

A number of distinguished mathematicians will speak at the conference. The award will provide supports for graduate students, early career researchers, people from underrepresented groups, and researchers who are not funded by the NSF and would like to have an opportunity to participate in this conference and to present their research works. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: https://sites.google.com/view/neam2019/home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Northeastern Analysis Meeting (NEAM 2019) was organized in order to maintain an annual, rotating analysis conference in the Northeast, modeled on the long established SEAM (Southeastern Analysis Meeting). Each year this meeting is held, the latest ideas and developments in mathematical analysis are disseminated and exchanged among a large audience including many early-career mathematicians and graduate students. In 2019, the meeting featured 11 plenary talks on various topics from the fields of harmonic analysis, complex analysis, geometric function theory, and others. There were about 70 registered participants in total.

In addition to plenary lectures, the conference included three parallel sessions of contributed talks. It also included time for informal networking, which is valuable for early career development of graduate students and young researchers. The conference had strong representation of women and members of minority groups in mathematical sciences. It connected early-career mathematicians with more senior researchers, some of whom are nationally renowned as mentors. The meeting also immersed graduate students in the some of the most current and cutting edge topics in analysis.

The award covered the travel and lodging of early-career mathematicians who would not be otherwise able to attend the event. Participants came not only from Northeast of the United States, but also from California, Texas, several Midwestern states, and Canada.
